input:
Based on the provided context, the rewritten input would be:

What is the recommended diagnostic method for females with suspected uterine cavity disorder, considering the conditional recommendation for saline infusion sonohysterography (SIS) over hysterosalpingogram (HSG) and the feasibility of using 2D US in resource-limited settings?
expected_output: According to the provided context, the recommended diagnostic method for females with suspected uterine cavity disorder is saline infusion sonohysterography (SIS) rather than hysterosalpingogram (HSG), as suggested by the World Health Organization (WHO). However, in resource-limited settings, healthcare providers may choose to use 2D ultrasound (US) instead, with follow-up required for women who are negative on 2D US but still suspected of uterine cavity disorder due to high rates of false negatives.
context:
xviiExecutive summary
Executive summary Intro Rationale & methodology Approach & management Prevention Diagnosis Treatment Dissemination Research gaps
Recommendation 
for the diagnosis 
of infertility due 
to uterine cavity 
disorder (cont.) 
For females with infertility due to suspected uterine cavity disorder, 
WHO suggests assessing the uterine cavity with saline infusion 
sonohysterography (SIS) rather than hysterosalpingogram (HSG). (Conditional 
recommendation, very low certainty of evidence)
Remark: 
• Health care providers may choose to use 2D US rather than HSG when 
resources are limited. Follow-up would be required for women who are 
negative on 2D US but still suspected of uterine cavity disorder because of 
high rates of false negatives.
Recommendations for the 
diagnosis of male-factor 
infertility 
Recommendation 
for semen analysis 
 For males (in couples with infertility) with one or more semen parameters 
outside the WHO reference ranges, WHO sugg ests repeating the semen 
analysis after a minimum of 11 weeks. (Conditional recommendation, very 
low certainty of evidence)
For males (in couples with infertility) with all semen parameters within the 
WHO reference ranges, WHO suggests not repeating the semen analysis. 
(Conditional recommendation, very low certainty of evidence)
 Remark: 
• The latest edition of the WHO laboratory manual for the examination and 
processing of human semen provides WHO reference ranges for semen 
parameters and details about the standardized procedures for semen 
collection and analysis.
Recommendation for the 
diagnosis of unexplained-
factor infertility 
 
WHO suggests making a diagnosis of unexplained infertility in a couple 
when all the following have occurred:
• failure to achieve pregnancy after 12 months of regular unprotected 
sexual intercourse;
• normal physical examination and medical history in both the male and 
female;
• presumptive confirmation of ovulation and  patent tubes in the female 
partner; and
• semen parameters that are within the WHO reference ranges in the 
male partner.
(Conditional recommendation, very low certainty of evidence)

xixExecutive summary
Executive summary Intro Rationale & methodology Approach & management Prevention Diagnosis Treatment Dissemination Research gaps
Recommendations 
for the treatment 
of infertility due to 
tubal disease (cont.) 
For females aged < 35 years with severe tubal disease (Hull and Rutherford 
grade III), WHO suggests in vitro fertilization (IVF) rather than surgery. 
(Conditional recommendation, very low certainty of evidence)
 Remark: 
• This recommendation does not apply to females who have had previous 
tubal sterilization.
For females aged ≥ 35 years with any tubal disease, WHO suggests in vitro 
fertilization (IVF) rather than surgery. (Conditional recommendation, very low 
certainty of evidence)
For females with tubal factor infertility due to hydrosalpinx, WHO suggests 
either salpingectomy or tubal occlusion before provision of in vitro 
fertilization (IVF). (Conditional recommendation, very low certainty evidence)
 Remark: 
• When selecting whether to use salpingectomy or tubal occlusion, consider 
feasibility, availability of trained health care providers and presence of 
adhesions.
For females with tubal factor infertility caused by hydrosalpinx, WHO 
suggests either salpingectomy or tubal occlusion rather than transvaginal 
aspiration of hydrosalpingeal fluid before provision of in vitro fertilization 
(IVF). (Conditional recommendation, very low certainty of evidence)
 Remark: 
• In settings where salpingectomy and tubal occlusion are not available or 
feasible, transvaginal aspiration may be offered.
Recommendation 
for the treatment 
of infertility due 
to uterine cavity 
disorder 
For females with infertility and uterine septum who have no history of 
recurrent pregnancy loss, WHO suggests that hysteroscopic septum 
resection (septoplasty) not be performed. (Conditional recommendation, low 
certainty of evidence)

xxiExecutive summary
Executive summary Intro Rationale & methodology Approach & management Prevention Diagnosis Treatment Dissemination Research gaps
Recommendations 
for the treatment of 
varicocele (cont.) 
For males with infertility undergoing surgical treatment of varicocele, WHO 
suggests using microscopic surgery rather than other surgical procedures. 
(Conditional recommendation, very low certainty of evidence)
 Remarks: 
• Subinguinal microsurgery is a common surgical varicocelectomy 
procedure, while other surgical procedures include non-microscopic 
open approaches (such as inguinal and retroperitoneal) and laparoscopic 
methods.
• In settings where the expertise to perform microscopic surgery is not 
available, other surgical techniques may be used.
• This recommendation applies to males with varicocele in couples with 
infertility who are not undergoing treatment with assisted reproductive 
technology (ART).
For males with infertility undergoing non-microscopic surgical treatment of 
varicocele, WHO suggests using either inguinal or retroperitoneal surgical 
procedures. (Conditional recommendation, very low certainty of evidence)
 Remarks: 
• When selecting whether to use an inguinal or retroperitoneal surgical 
procedure, consider feasibility and the availability of trained health 
care providers.
• This recommendation applies to males with varicocele in couples with 
infertility who are not undergoing treatment with assisted reproductive 
technology (ART).
Recommendations for the 
treatment of unexplained 
infertility 
Recommendations 
for first-line 
management 
of couples with 
unexplained 
infertility 
For couples with unexplained infertility, WHO suggests expectant 
management rather than unstimulated intrauterine insemination (U-IUI). 
(Conditional recommendation, low certainty of evidence)
 Remarks: 
• Expectant management refers to monitoring the couple with the 
expectation that pregnancy will be achieved without medical intervention. 
It includes providing advice on lifestyle and the most fertile days of the 
menstrual cycle, and monitoring if pregnancy will occur; however, no 
medical intervention is provided.
• The duration of expectant management was typically 3–6 months in 
studies informing this recommendation.

input: Consider the feasibility of 2D US as an alternative to HSG in low-resource settings.
expected_output: In low-resource settings, 2D US may be a feasible alternative to HSG for assessing uterine cavity disorders in females with suspected infertility. However, it's essential to note that 2D US has high rates of false negatives, and follow-up would be required for women who are negative on 2D US but still suspected of uterine cavity disorder.

input: Delve into the development of fertility care standards and protocols for universal health coverage.
expected_output:
To develop fertility care standards and protocols for universal health coverage, the World Health Organization (WHO) recommends the following:

1. **Provision of health financing**: Ensure that health financing is available to cover fertility care services, including prevention, diagnosis, and treatment.
2. **Trained personnel**: Provide training for healthcare professionals to deliver high-quality fertility care services.
3. **Medicines, equipment, and infrastructure**: Ensure that fertility care services have access to necessary medicines, equipment, and infrastructure.
4. **Effective monitoring**: Establish robust health information systems to monitor fertility care services and identify areas for improvement.
5. **Basic fertility care interventions**: Make basic fertility care interventions available at the primary health care level to enhance service coverage.
6. **Financial protection**: Ensure that fertility care services are provided while upholding financial protection, preventing catastrophic expenditures due to out-of-pocket costs.

These standards and protocols will help achieve universal health coverage and ensure that fertility care services are accessible, equitable, and of high quality.
context:
Guideline for the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of infertility
6
Executive summary Intro Rationale & methodology Approach & management Prevention Diagnosis Treatment Dissemination Research gaps
need them. However, in many countries, infertility 
services and policies are not prioritized or included 
in health systems, including services or financing 
(87–89). Achieving universal health coverage will 
require provision of health financing, trained 
personnel, medicines, equipment, infrastructure 
and effective monitoring of services through 
robust health information systems. Ensuring 
that fertility care is provided while upholding 
financial protection is essential given the risk 
for catastrophic expenditures because of out-of-
pocket costs. People often incur large out-of-pocket 
costs to access services for preventing, diagnosing 
or treating infertility ( 83, 90). In addition, ensuring 
that basic fertility care interventions are available 
at the primary health care  level will contribute to 
enhanced service coverage. 
References
1. International Classification of Diseases, 11th 
Revision (ICD-11). Geneva: World Health 
Organization; 2018 (https://www.who.int/
classifications/icd/en/).
2. Zegers-Hochschild F, Adamson GD, de Mouzon 
J, Ishihara O, Mansour R, Nygren K et al. The 
international committee for monitoring assisted 
reproductive technology (ICMART) and the 
World Health Organization (WHO) revised 
glossary on ART terminology, 2009. Hum Reprod. 
2009;24 (11):2683-7 (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.
fertnstert.2009.09.009).
3. Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of 
Discrimination against Women. Treaty Series, 
vol 1249, Part IV; Article 16. New York: United 
Nations General Assembly; 1979.
4. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights 
(UDHR). New York: United Nations; 1948.
5. Beaujouan E, Berghammer C. The gap between 
lifetime fertility intentions and completed fertility 
in Europe and the United States: a cohort 
approach. Popul Res Policy Rev. 2019;38:507-35 
(ht tps://doi.org/10.1007/s11113- 019 - 09516 -3).
6. Infertility prevalence estimates: 1990–2021. 
Geneva: World Health Organization; 2023 
(https://apps.who.int/iris/handle/10665/366700).
7. Chemaitelly H, Majed A, Abu-Hijleh F, Blondeel 
K, Matsaseng TC, Kiarie J et al. Global 
epidemiology of Neisseria gonorrhoeae in 
infertile populations: systematic review, meta-
analysis and metaregression. Sex Transm Infect. 
2021;97(2):157-69 (https://doi.org/10.1136/
sextrans-2020-054515).
8. Larsen U. Primary and secondary infertility 
in sub-Saharan Africa. Int J Epidemiol. 
2000;29(2):285-91 (https://doi.org/10.1093/
ije/29.2.285).
9. Rutstein SO, Shah IH. Infecundity, infertility, 
and childlessness in developing countries. DHS 
Comparative Reports No. 9. Calverton, USA: ORC 
Macro and World Health Organization; 2004 
(https://dhsprogram.com/pubs/pdf/CR9/CR9.pdf).
10. Mascarenhas MN, Flaxman SR, Boerma T, 
Vanderpoel S, Stevens GA. National, regional, 
and global trends in infertility prevalence since 
1990: a systematic analysis of 277 health surveys. 
PLoS Med. 2012;9(12):e1001356 (https://doi.
org/10.1371/journal.pmed.1001356).
11. Rowe PJ. Infertility. World Health. 1987:20-1 
(https://iris.who.int/handle/10665/53389)
12. Rowe PJ, Comhaire FH, Hargreave TB, Mellows HJ. 
WHO manual for the standardized investigation 
and diagnosis of the infertile couple. Cambridge: 
Cambridge University Press; 1993 (https://iris.

input:
Considering the context of the guideline for the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of infertility, which emphasizes the importance of addressing infertility services and policies in health systems, the rewritten input would be:

What specific information about infertility is being requested, and how does it relate to the provision of health financing, trained personnel, medicines, equipment, infrastructure, and effective monitoring of services through robust health information systems?

This rewritten input adds a constraint by asking for a specific connection to the provision of health services, which is a key aspect of the guideline. It also requires the answer to be factually correct based on the information provided in the context.
expected_output:
The rewritten input is requesting information about the specific aspects of infertility that are relevant to the provision of health financing, trained personnel, medicines, equipment, infrastructure, and effective monitoring of services through robust health information systems.

According to the guideline, ensuring that fertility care is provided while upholding financial protection is essential, given the risk for catastrophic expenditures due to out-of-pocket costs (83, 90). People often incur large out-of-pocket costs to access services for preventing, diagnosing, or treating infertility.

Therefore, the specific information being requested relates to the need for:

* Provision of health financing to support fertility care
* Trained personnel to provide fertility services
* Medicines, equipment, and infrastructure to support fertility care
* Effective monitoring of services through robust health information systems to ensure that fertility care is provided while upholding financial protection.

This information is crucial for achieving universal health coverage and ensuring that fertility care is accessible and affordable for all individuals.

input:
Based on the provided context, the rewritten input would be:

What are the key recommendations and evidence-based practices outlined in the guideline for the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of infertility, and how do they address the complex interplay between biological, social, and psychological factors affecting fertility?

This rewritten input adds an additional layer of complexity by:

1. Specifying the type of information sought (key recommendations and evidence-based practices)
2. Emphasizing the need to address the complex interplay between biological, social, and psychological factors affecting fertility
3. Using more precise language to convey the scope of the guideline

The rewritten input remains fully answerable from the information in the context, which includes various studies, research papers, and guidelines related to infertility.
expected_output:
The guideline for the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of infertility emphasizes the importance of addressing the complex interplay between biological, social, and psychological factors affecting fertility. Key recommendations and evidence-based practices outlined in the guideline include:

1. **Multidisciplinary approach**: A team-based approach involving healthcare professionals from various disciplines, including reproductive medicine, psychology, and social work, to provide comprehensive care to individuals and couples experiencing infertility (Thoma et al., 2021).
2. **Biological and social assessments**: Comprehensive assessments of both biological and social factors, including lifestyle, relationships, and socioeconomic status, to identify potential causes of infertility and develop targeted interventions (Thoma et al., 2021).
3. **Evidence-based treatments**: The use of evidence-based treatments, such as assisted reproductive technologies (ART), to address infertility, while also considering the potential risks and benefits associated with these treatments (Lazzari et al., 2021).
4. **Psychological support**: The provision of psychological support and counseling to individuals and couples experiencing infertility, to address the emotional and psychological impacts of infertility (Fisher et al., 2012).
5. **Social and cultural sensitivity**: The recognition of the social and cultural contexts in which infertility occurs, and the development of interventions that are sensitive to these contexts (Inhorn, 2004).
6. **Global access to care**: The promotion of global access to infertility care, including ART, to address the disparities in access to care and improve reproductive health outcomes (Ombelet, 2025).

These recommendations and evidence-based practices are grounded in the existing literature and research on infertility, and are designed to address the complex interplay between biological, social, and psychological factors affecting fertility.

References:

Inhorn, M. C. (2004). Middle Eastern masculinities in the age of new reproductive technologies: Male infertility and stigma in Egypt and Lebanon. Medical Anthropology Quarterly, 18(2), 162-182.

Fisher, J. R., & Hammarberg, K. (2012). Psychological and social aspects of infertility in men: An overview of the evidence and implications for psychologically informed clinical care and future research. Asian Journal of Andrology, 14(1), 121.

Lazzari, E., Gray, E., & Chambers, G. M. (2021). The contribution of assisted reproductive technology to fertility rates and parity transition. Demography Research, 45, 1081-1096.

Ombelet, W. (2025). Global access to infertility care. Fertility and Sterility, S0015-0282(25)00085-8.

Thoma, M., Fledderjohann, J., Cox, C., & Kantum Adageba, R. (2021). Biological and social aspects of human infertility: A global perspective. Oxford University Press.

Note: The references provided are a selection of the relevant studies and research papers mentioned in the context, and are intended to support the key recommendations and evidence-based practices outlined in the guideline.

input: How do various factors, including biological, social, and psychological aspects, collectively contribute to the complex phenomenon of infertility, as highlighted in the provided research papers and guidelines?
expected_output: Infertility is a complex phenomenon influenced by various biological, social, and psychological factors. Research papers and guidelines (e.g., #67, #72, #73, #75, #76, #77) highlight the interplay between these factors. Biological aspects, such as sperm parameters (#49, #50), hormonal imbalances, and genetic factors, contribute to infertility. Social factors, including cultural and societal norms, access to assisted reproductive technologies (ART), and economic constraints (#84, #85, #87, #88), also play a significant role. Psychological aspects, such as stress, anxiety, and stigma (#71, #74, #75, #76), can further exacerbate the issue. Additionally, gender differences in experiences with and adjustments to infertility (#70, #77) and the impact of infertility on men's general health (#73) are also documented. Overall, the collective contribution of these factors underscores the need for a comprehensive and nuanced approach to addressing infertility.
